entry.title: PM Order cannot control budget from the WBS element of the PS module.
entry.content:
Dear All,

I would like to control the budget for PM Orders by creating a WBS and assigning a budget to it. Then, I assign the WBS to the Functional Location. When creating a PR/PO from a PM Order with account assignment type = F (PM Order), the system does not recognize the budget commitment from the WBS.

Is there any way to control the budget for PM Orders in the Public Cloud?

Best regards,

Keratiya D.

entry.title: Process Integration Pipeline Extension - Restart via Data Store
entry.content:
If you use the Process Integration Pipeline concept on your SAP Cloud Integration tenant, then you'll be familiar with the error handling process. In case of a message processing error, the message will be retried from the JMS processing queues and upon reaching the maximum number of retries, the message is sent to a Dead Letter Queue (DLQ) to stop further processing. The message then has to be moved from the DLQ back to the processing queues of the pipeline. 

The move feature in the queue monitor only enables you to move all messages within a queue. Currently, you can't move a single message from one queue to another. Selective message move is a planned roadmap item for Q3 2025.

There are multiple restrictions imposed by this retry handling process:

  • It is not possible to figure out to which scenarios the messages belong in the DLQ
  • It is not possible to schedule a restart job with periodic retries of erroneous messages.
  • It is not possible to execute selective move of messages from JMS queue (to be solved by Q3 2025 as mentioned).
  • There is no API to move messages from DLQ to normal processing queues.
  • There is no API to read JMS queue content and select required messages based on query conditions (JMS Message ID cannot be set from an Integration Flow and there is not any configurable tag for JMS message).

An additional aspect is the resource limit of the JMS broker:

  • There is a hard size limit of JMS broker and JMS queues (default 95% of broker). In case of an unplanned outage of a receiver system, messages might be flooding generic pipeline queues like Outbound (Q4) JMS queue.

To solve these issues, we have created a package called the Process Integration Pipeline Extension - Restart via Data Store which is now available in SAP Business Accelerator Hub. This package helps to automate message retries via scheduled jobs and APIs by utilizing Data Stores instead of DLQs on the JMS broker. There is no change required to the standard Process Integration Pipeline package due to the available custom error handling extension from version 1.0.5 on.

This blog describes the concept of the extension, but not the detailed configuration of each Integration Flow.. A detailed configuration guide is attached to the Integration Package.

Integration Package contents

The package consists of multiple Integration Flows and a Script Collection. Below schema describes the logical connection between the Integration Flows.

 

  • Pipeline DS Retry - Custom Error Handling with Data Stores. This Integration Flow implements Custom Error Handling for exceptions occurring in the generic steps of the Process Integration Pipeline. It leverages the public Pipeline extension exit, as described in the Custom Exception Handling documentation. Its primary function is to determine whether retries should continue through the JMS persistence layer or, if all configured JMS retries are exhausted, to move the message out of the queue into the Data Store while capturing all necessary restart attributes and forming the Data Store entry body.
  • Pipeline DS Retry - Restart Executor from Data Store to JMS. This Integration Flow handles message reprocessing by moving messages from the Data Store back to the source JMS processing queue, allowing the JMS layer to manage the actual retry process. It is triggered via Process Direct and requires XML input specifying the source Data Store, maximum retry count, and the retry subject ‚Äì either a list of Data Store entry names or an Interface PID for dynamically retrying all associated Data Store entries.
  • Pipeline DS Retry - Template - Restart Job. This Integration Flow represents a Restart Job that automatically reprocesses messages from the Data Store based on assigned restart configuration profiles. Execution is scheduled using a Start Timer event. Provided as a template, this Integration Flow allows for the creation of multiple customized copies in a custom package, with different Job Profiles maintained in the Partner Directory.
  • Pipeline API - Data Store Manage Retries (Optional). This Integration Flow enables on-demand restart operations via API clients like Postman. It exposes an HTTP endpoint to trigger restarts for specified Data Store entries or based on selection criteria. Additional operations allow users to retrieve a list of Data Stores in the tenant, fetch entries from a specific Data Store, and move entries between Data Stores (e.g., transferring entries from the ‚ÄúRetry‚Äù Data Store to the ‚ÄúNoRetry‚Äù Data Store to prevent automatic retriggering). 
  • Pipeline API - Data Store Manage Entries (Optional). This Integration Flow provides API-based management of Data Store entries, separate from the "Manage Retries" API, to enforce role-based access. It allows users to read messages from a selected Data Store, delete messages (individually or based on query conditions), and add messages to the Data Store (this capability can be disabled at the Integration Flow level).

Data Store Entry Format

The Pipeline DS Retry - Custom Error Handling with Data Stores Integration Flow will write the messages into Data Stores in a specific pattern which can be used to easily identify the corresponding scenario, message restart by filter criteria.  The following pattern is used:

PartnerId~PipelineStage(~Receiver )~MplId~UTC-Timestamp(~RetryCount )

  • PartnerId (Mandatory) ‚Äì A unique identifier in the Process Integration Pipeline that defines the configuration scenario. It is derived from the sender system name and sender interface name. More details can be found in the Partner ID documentation.
  • PipelineStage (Mandatory) ‚Äì Identifies the stage in the Process Integration Pipeline where the exception occurred. It uses predefined two-letter identifiers enclosed in parentheses (e.g., (IB)), resulting in a four-character code:
    • (IB) ‚Äì Inbound Stage: The message was received by an inbound Integration Flow, stored in the first JMS queue, and encountered an exception during the next processing step.
    • (RD) ‚Äì Receiver Determination Stage: The inbound conversion was successful, but an error occurred while identifying the receiver system.
    • (ID) ‚Äì Interface Determination Stage: The receiver system was identified, but an error occurred while determining the target inbound interface for that receiver (i.e., the Process Direct endpoint of the outbound Integration Flow).
    • (OB) ‚Äì Outbound Stage: The message was successfully routed, but an error occurred during message conversion to the outbound format or while transmitting data to the receiver. This is the most common error-handling stage.
    • (NA) ‚Äì The error originated from an unknown or custom Integration Flow (e.g., a copy of the generic flow or an interface-specific flow connected to the retry extension).
  • Receiver (Optional) ‚Äì The receiver business system or alias to which the message is to be delivered. This field is optional because in the |IB| and |RD| stages, the receiver is still unknown. It is assigned only starting from the |ID| stage.
  • MplId (Mandatory) ‚Äì The Message Processing Log ID (Message GUID) of the erroneous message, a 28-character unique identifier assigned to each message in Cloud Integration. Even though the Message Processing Log ID is directly visible in the Data Store UI, this identifier is required to guarantee uniqueness in terms of Data Store entry ID as a timestamp will not guarantee uniqueness.
  • UTC-Timestamp (Mandatory) ‚Äì A timestamp marking when the message first entered the Custom Error Handling Integration Flow. It follows the ISO 8601 format: yyyy-MM-dd'T'HH:mm:ss.SSS'Z' (Example: 2025-04-20T06:51:11.123Z)
  • RetryCount (Optional) ‚Äì A counter tracking Data Store restart attempts. For a new erroneous message using Data Store-based restarts, this counter starts at 0 and increments with each retry attempt. This prevents exceeding the maximum allowed retries (MaxDataStoreRetries).

The entry written to the Data Store contains the message payload and the potential attachments in a Base64-encoded format. Additionally a message header is included which contains metadata required for further processing such as:

  • The source JMS queue where the message will be placed for reprocessing
  • The entry name of the Data Store record
  • The Data Store name used for reprocessing
  • The maximum retry count assigned to the interface in the Partner Directory (or a default of 3 retries from the Data Store)
  • The exception message, also stored in Base64-encoded format

The structure looks as follows:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<Message>
	<MsgHeader>
		<RestartQueue>${property.SourceJMSQueue}</RestartQueue>
		<EntryID>${property.EntryID}</EntryID>
		<RetryDataStore>${property.RetryDataStore}</RetryDataStore>
		<MaxRetryCount>${property.MaxDataStoreRetries}</MaxRetryCount>
		<Error>exception.message.Base64encoded</Error>
	</MsgHeader>
	<Payload>Payload.Base64encoded</Payload>
	<Attachments> (minOccurs="0")
		<Attachment> (maxOccurs="unbounded")
			<AttachmentName>attachmentName</AttachmentName>
			<AttachmentContentType>contType</AttachmentContentType>
			<AttachmentContent>content.Base64</AttachmentContent>
		</Attachment>
	</Attachments>
</Message>

 

Data Store Options

The extension package utilizes two data store options: RetryStore and NoRetryStore. The Integration Flow Pipeline DS Retry - Custom Error Handling with Data Stores determines ‚Äì based on the number of JMS retries, PartnerId configuration in Partner Directory and the pipeline Stage where the error occurred ‚Äì into which kind of Data Store the message is placed.

  • RetryStore ‚Äì If a message should be automatically restarted in case of an error in inbound or outbound processing or in the integrated runtime, it will be put into this store. The messages in this store option can be restarted via the Restart Job Template Integration Flow. If the maximum number of retries is not reached for restarted messages, they will be put back into this store with an increased retry counter.
  • NoRetryStore ‚Äì If a message should not be restarted automatically in case of failing receiver or interface determination or when the maximum number of retries have been reached by an already restarted message, it will be put into this store. The messages in this store option can be restarted explicitly via the Integration Flow Pipeline API - Data Store Manage Retries or via even by the Restart Job if needed.

Restart configuration settings for scenarios

The Integration Flow Pipeline DS Retry - Custom Error Handling with Data Stores will put the failed messages into Data Stores based on PartnerId configuration defined in the Partner Directory via String Parameters. If the configuration is missing in the Partner Directory for a given PartnerId, default values will be applied. 

  • RetryDataStore ‚Äì Defines the name of the Data Store where the erroneous message should be stored in case of exceeding maximum number of retry attempts at JMS layer.
    • Note that even when set to a specific value, messages destined for the NoRetryStore will have the ‚Äú_NoRetry‚Äù postfix appended to the Data Store name and they require no explicit configuration.
    • If RetryDataStore String parameter is not set for the PartnerId, then the data store names used will be <PartnerId>_Retry and <PartnerId>_NoRetry.
  • restartMode ‚Äì Can be set to either DS (Data Store) or JMS (JMS queue) to define how the messages should be restarted. Default option is DS if not set.
    • DS: putting a message back to the JMS queue, but in case of an error immediately taking it to a Data Store (preferred and default). 
    • JMS: putting a message back to the JMS queue and in case of an error executing retries in this JMS queue according to the maximum number of JMS retries.
  • MaxDataStoreRetries ‚Äì Defines the number of retries after a restart of a message. If the limit is reached, the messaged is moved into the ‚Äú_NoRetry‚Äù Data Store. Default number is 5.

 

Restart job configuration 

The Integration Flow ‚ÄúPipeline DS Retry - Template - Restart Job‚Äù relies on the configuration of different Restart Job Profiles. Multiple variants can be configured to have different scheduled versions of the Restart Job for specific interfaces.

Note that interfaces must be explicitly specified, no regex pattern is applicable in the profiles. Also, there is no default Job Profile applicable for all integration scenarios, i.e. if there is no defined job profile for the interface ‚Äì the messages won‚Äôt be restarted

  • Status ‚Äì Can be set to ‚Äúactive‚Äù or ‚Äúinactive‚Äù.
  • InterfacePidList ‚Äì Defines the list of the interfaces (or integration scenarios) for which the message restarts should be triggered. Multiple scenarios can be set by using the character semicolon ‚Äú;‚Äù as a delimiter. The Restart Job will consider the scenario-specific configuration defined in the Partner Directory (assigned Data Store, number of retries and restart mode).
  • Store ‚Äì ( If not set, Retry stores will be always used (with value Retry). In case of emergencies or if the API based restart can‚Äôt be used, restart from the NoRetryStore can be set for scheduled Restart Jobs.

Filters within the Restart Job Profile. If not set, all entries from the given Data Store will be restarted.

  • Receiver ‚Äì ( Receiver name to select all the entries from the Data Store that belong to the specified receiver (for the stages when receiver is unknown (e.g. Inbound), the value ‚Äúnull‚Äù can be sent and then all entries without receiver will be selected). Example of value: ‚ÄúS4HCLNT100‚Äù. Note that the parameter setting is global for all interfaces maintained in the InterfacePidList parameter, it can‚Äôt be set for each interface separately.
  • TimeFrom ‚Äì (Optional parameter): Interval start timestamp in UTC format to select all the entries from the Data Store that have timestamp in DS Entry name later than specified timestamp. Example of value: ‚Äú2025-06-01T09:00:00.000Z‚Äù.
  • TimeTo ‚Äì (Optional parameter): Interval end timestamp in UTC format to select all the entries from the Data Store that have timestamp in DS Entry name earlier than specified timestamp. Example of value: ‚Äú2025-06-02T09:00:00.000Z‚Äù.

Below screenshot shows a Restart Job profile with the optional parameters.

The Restart Job from the template Integration Flow Pipeline DS Retry - Template - Restart Job can be configured to use a schedule-based trigger (start Timer event). Default configuration is to run On Deployment.

On-Demand Restarts or Data Store management via HTTP API

There are 2 optional Integration Flows in the package which can be used for on-demand operations. They expose 2 HTTP endpoints to manage Retry related operations and to manage Data Store entries. The functionality is divided into 2 Integration Flows for more granular control on authorization level who is allowed to call Restart operations only and who is allowed to Cancel messages (manipulate Data Store entries).

These 2 additional Integration Flows are acting as APIs for more granular control of messages in the Data Stores than the Restart Job. On the other hand, these must be handled with caution as it requires deep understanding of the extension package on how to restart a corresponding package.

Configuration steps to use the package

  1. Configure and Deploy mandatory Integration Artefacts of DS Restart Extension package.
  2. Assign Data Store Restart Configuration for Configuration Scenarios in Partner Directory.
  3. Enable Custom Exception Handling in generic Integration Flows of Process Integration Pipeline package.
  4. Create Restart Job Profiles in Partner Directory.
  5. Create a Restart Job Integration Flow from Template, Configure Parameters and Deploy.
  6. (Optional) Configure and Deploy Integration Flows for On-Demand Restarts or Data Store management via HTTP API.

Further improvements

We are planning to add further improvements to the package such as:

  • Configurable no restart stages 
  • Add default Restart Job Profile if scenarios are not maintained explicitly
  • Catch mapping errors in the outbound stages and move these messages into the NoRetry store (as there is no option to edit a message like in SAP PO)
  • Catch routing errors for the Integrated Messaging Runtime
  • Current Receiver filter in the Restart Job Profile setting is global, needs to be changed to scenario-specific filter
  • Add extension point in the Pipeline DS Retry - Custom Error Handling with Data Stores Integration Flow for potential custom alerting requirement

If you have any further ideas to enhance the package, let us know in the comments.

Conclusion

The Process Integration Pipeline Extension - Restart via Data Store package offers a viable solution to the challenges faced when utilizing the Process Integration Pipeline concept. By automating message retries through scheduled jobs and APIs, and shifting reliance from Dead Letter Queues to Data Stores, users can effectively manage message restarts as an alternative to the standard error handling of the Pipeline concept. By leveraging the Pipeline‚Äôs custom exit for error handling, this can be achieved without requiring changes to the standard Process Integration Pipeline package.

entry.title: Integrating SAP CIS with SAP SuccessFactors: A Guide to Standard and Hybrid Integration
entry.content:
Overview

SAP Cloud Identity Services (CIS) is a robust suite of tools designed to manage identity and access across the SAP ecosystem. This blog explores how CIS integrates with SAP SuccessFactors, focusing on hybrid integration patterns that enable seamless user authentication and identity provisioning in complex enterprise landscapes.

There are three primary flavors to integrating

  1. Standard Integration (Recommended)
  2. Proxy Integration using CIS(external IDP as authentication provider)
  3. Hybrid Integration using CIS (external IDP or both external IDP and CIS as authentication provider) without SF being the source of user records to CIS

 SAP SuccessFactors with SAP Cloud Identity Services:

Option 1: Integration Between SAP SuccessFactors and SAP CIS (Standard)

This is the most recommended method, fully aligned with SAP‚Äôs best practices for managing user identities. It involves the following steps:

  1. Integrate SAP SuccessFactors with Identity Authentication: Run the upgrade job in the SAP SuccessFactors Upgrade Center to enable features and establish trust between SF and CIS.
  2. Confirm that user sync is set up in Identity Provisioning in SAP Cloud Identity Services: Set up sync jobs with Identity Provisioning. Ensure that the user that is configured in the Identity Provisioning
  3. Review the default configurations: Review the default configuration of the Identity Authentication service to determine if it meets your requirements or if additional configuration is required.
  4. Additional configuration optional features:Configuration options in Identity Authentication include:  Password policy settings, Single sign-on (SSO) etc
  5. Activate Identity Authentication (IAS): Turn on the Identity Authentication service

This ensures standardized, low-effort configuration and a consistent integration experience. More Details - SAP Help

Option 2: Using SAP CIS as a Proxy (Standard)

Many enterprises already use external identity providers (e.g., Azure AD, Okta) and want to continue doing so while adopting SAP applications.

By integrating the external IdP with CIS, organizations can:

  • Maintain centralized identity governance.
  • Enable secure authentication across SAP SuccessFactors, SAC, and Joule.

In this approach CIS acts as a proxy and user authentication is taken care by the external Identity provider like Entra, OKTA, etc. CIS may/may not have user records in its internal store (based on your requirements). Federation can be used if user records exist. Synching user records in CIS unlock features like SAC and future innovations such as SAP Joule, as they're a key prerequisite for access. Ideal for customers wanting minimal disruption to existing identity infrastructure while gaining access to SAP‚Äôs innovation roadmap.

Option 3: Hybrid Integration ‚Äî Using SAP CIS as a Proxy Without Standard SF User Sync.

Further details in this blog primarily focuses on this hybrid model.

Key Characteristics:

  • SAP SuccessFactors is not the user provisioning source.
  • CIS can act as a proxy or both proxy and IDP
  • User profile data is synced to CIS from a different /external source to enable:
    • Access to services like SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) and SAP Joule
    • Federated authentication via external IdPs

This method provides the flexibility to maintain external Identity manager to keep managing users in an enterprise while using SAP CIS to enabling access to SAP applications and to access new features and innovations.

‚öôÔ∏èUnderstanding Standard Integration Behavior

SAP‚Äôs standard SF-to-CIS integration includes two background jobs(in case if SAC exist):

Job 1: User Sync from SuccessFactors to IAS

  • Reads user data from SF.
  • Creates users in CIS.
  • Generates a Global User ID, and store it in personKeyNav/GlobalUserId in SF.
  • Populates CustomAttribute1 if the user has SAC access permissions.

Job 2: Sync to SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC)

  • Reads user data from SF and syncs only users with access to embedded analytics to SAC
  • Prevents SAC user creation for ineligible accounts.

‚öôÔ∏èAdapting the Integration for an External Data Source

If you're not syncing users from SAP SF (i.e., using an external Data source like Identity manager), the standard jobs need to be customized to use IAS as the source and SAC as the target. It is very important to make sure that only users who have permission to embedded analytics should be synched to SAC. This step can be done either inside the cync job or can be taken care at source level (making sure to populate the custom attribute only if user has permission to access SAC)

‚ö†Ô∏èTo configure this job, you can modify the existing target or create a new one. If creating a new target, an SAP support ticket is required to set credentials (OAuth token URL, Client ID, and Secret).

üìãStep-by-Step: Hybrid Integration with External Source

  1. Integrate SAP SuccessFactors with Identity Authentication: Run the upgrade job in the SAP SuccessFactors Upgrade Center to enable features and establish trust between SF and CIS.
  2. Review the default configurations: Review the default configuration of the Identity Authentication service to determine if it meets your requirements or if additional configuration is required.
  3. Create Admin User for SCIM Access: Use SCIM APIs to push user records from the external system.
  4. Retain Global User ID (Optional): If needed, set the Global User ID in CIS to a unique external ID or let the system generate one. This Global User Id needs to be updated in SF at (personKeyNav/GlobalUserId).
  5. Sync to SAC
    Run a custom job (IAS ‚Üí SAC) to:
    • Check SAC access rights.
    • Create users accordingly.

‚öôÔ∏è Addressing Common Technical Challenges in Hybrid Integration

1: Managing Different Subject Name Identifiers (SNI) Across Applications

In hybrid, multi-application environments, it's common for login identifiers to vary across systems. SAP CIS supports multiple Subject Name Identifiers (SNI) per application, allowing flexibility. For scenarios where CIS login name is taken by another application as the identifier and it doesn't have the same value as username in SF then any other field supported field can be used for SNI. 

For SAP SuccessFactors (SF), it's essential to ensure that the runtime value of the SNI must align with the SF username field to enable proper user identification.

Note: Expression-based SNI mapping is supported, but functionality is currently limited. Use with caution and review configuration thoroughly before implementation

2: Can SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) Work Without a Direct Sync from SF to CIS?

Yes, Though it is recommended to sync it from SF SAC does not require a direct user synchronization from SF. However, there's a critical requirement to enable user access:

Ensure CustomAttribute1 is correctly populated, as it is used to determine analytics access. Regardless of the data source, this attribute must be synced to SAC via CIS.

3: Can CustomAttribute1 Be Replaced with Another Attribute?

Absolutely. CustomAttribute1 is just a label. In SAP CIS, custom attributes are internally stored as an array, offering flexibility in how they're used.

If you choose to use a different custom attribute:

  • Ensure the transformation logic is updated accordingly, to confirm that consuming applications (e.g., SAC) are configured to read the new attribute.

  • Update the SNI mapping to reference the correct custom attribute.

4: Connecting Multiple SF Tenants to a Single CIS Tenant (with SAC for Each SF)

While technically possible, connecting multiple SuccessFactors tenants to the same CIS tenant, each with its own SAC instance, but it is not recommended. This setup introduces significant complexity in Managing user states across tenants.    

Conclusion

Integrating SAP SuccessFactors with SAP Cloud Identity Services offers flexibility, security, and alignment with SAP‚Äôs innovation roadmap. Whether through standard integration or a hybrid identity landscape using external IdPs, these methods empower organizations to centralize access control, reduce redundancy, and prepare for emerging technologies like SAP Joule.

entry.title: Scalar functions on CDS views
entry.content:
I have created and defined a scalar function called ZWBS_Description.

When implementing the function in the method returnWbsDescription in the corresponding amdp class, the method configuration that provides the result is already set ( in the scalar function definition and implementation reference).

I now would like to create the return value for my scalar function.
(The datasource, is a cds view entity ( based on an SAP table).)

My issue is, that I can't make a select on a CDS view. I get the following error.

In a table function the client dependency can be controlled, but I don't think that is possible for a scalar function. ( The annotation is not allowed. Makes sense, as the client field is always set in a CDS view in the background.)

I have taken a deep dive in the documentation
ABAP CDS - Scalar Functions | ABAP Keyword Documentation
but I can't find any solution regarding that.

My question is now, is it even possible to use a CDS view as a data source?
And on top of that, why (again) are we limited to SQLScript instead if ABAP SQL ?


More background information

entry.title: Re: Datasphere - HANA Cloud DB Remote Table (Insufficient...
entry.content:
You can grant the select access on HDI container to your Database user. there are couple of ways you can do.

1. Object owner of the container can grant the SELECT privilege on the Schema of the Container., you can run the SQL procedure for that. Instructions are in this clip at 10th min. 

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hbk7euYjCKo

2. You can create a hdbrole in the MTA project DB module and deploy, this role will be granted directly to the database user in the HANA cockpit --> user management. 

Note: For the connection, you may use a different admin user than DBADMIN, as it contains more privileges.

entry.title: Re: Providing initial data to your tenants in your multi-tenant application (CAP JAVA)
entry.content:
Hello,

thank you for this informative blog. We face the exact opposite issue: we have CSV files with config data that should ALWAYS be deployed to hana db after the deloyment of the mtar file. We run this command:

      cf run-task "$serverModuleName" --name "upgrade-all" --command "cds-mtx upgrade '*'"

but in the db it does not update the data content, only the schema. The data is generated in gen/data, but the cds-mtx just ignores it.

also in the logs he claims to write the logs to home/vcap/app/log/<tenantId>.log. But if we check via cf ssh there is no folder "logs" in the folder "app". Same as that he claims he deploys the gen/base folder in the app folder but there is no such gen folder.

 


How can we check the hdi deployment logs and how can we achieve that with every cds-mtx upgrade he also redeploys the provided CSVs? Is there a documentation for the options for cds-mtx upgrade?

entry.title: Re: Can BTP Service Alert Notification be used for SSL ce...
entry.content:
Ye,s it is possible to create alerts for expiring SSL certificates. The ANS catalog has services which expose such expiration notifications (such as the destination service). You can check the list of events on this link: Built-In Events | SAP Help Portal - some of them will have an expiration certificate event.

The other option would be to use the ANS as an alerting engine and create a configuration which will allow you to receive notifications when a certificate expires. More information on integrating the service can be found here Integrating with a Custom Application | SAP Help Portal.

entry.title: Serial Number Management with Inventory Sych in S4 Hana Public cloud & SAP Digital Manufacturing Clo
entry.content:
Serial Number Management with Inventory Synchronization Control from S4HANA public cloud

 

‚Ä¢            Need:  track and manage Serial Numbers Inventory Sych with audit trail in Digital Manufacturing cloud system, for Goods Receipt 101 and goods issue 261 Synchronization using

entry.title: Using SAP hana-client promises module with TypeScript
entry.content:
Hi all,

I've been using @SAP/hana-client Promises module for many years. A new project is being written on TypeScript, and importing "@sap/hana-client/extension/Promise.js" leads to message "Could not find a declaration file for module '@sap/hana-client/extension/Promise.js'. '(...)/node_modules/@sap/hana-client/extension/Promise.js' implicitly has an 'any' type.
If the '@sap/hana-client' package actually exposes this module, try adding a new declaration (.d.ts) file containing `declare module '@sap/hana-client/extension/Promise.js';". This makes type inferrence impossible on the downstream, so we need to manually type each variable/function declaration to not be of type any.
As @SAP/hana-client has a .d.ts file, I would expect the Promises module to be typed, but then it would probably be imported from the root of the module (as usual with any other lib), instead of being imported directly from the specific .js file.


With that context, I have 2 questions:
1) How/where can I raise an issue to the appropriate SAP team to have this correctly typed (and, even better, importable from the root)?
2) Is there a way we can "type the Promises module ourselves" (via type coercion from the types made available by @SAP/hana-client or something in that sense), so that types can be inferred as expected?

 

Thank you in advance,

Lawisch

entry.title: How can I connect to and run a query inside the provider HDI container/schema during subs
entry.content:
I'm working with a multitenant SAP CAP application and trying to insert custom details into a table (APP_SUBSCRIPTION) that resides in the provider HDI container (i.e., the provider schema) when a new tenant subscribes.

Here's the relevant part of my code:

const cds = require("@sap/cds");

cds.on("served", () => {
  const { "cds.xt.DeploymentService": ds } = cds.services;

  ds.after("subscribe", async (_, req) => {
    const result = await cds.tx({ tenant: null }, async (tx) => {
      try {
        const db = await cds.connect.to("providerDb");
        const res = await db.run("SELECT CURRENT_SCHEMA FROM DUMMY");
        console.log("schema --> " + JSON.stringify(res));
        return res;
      } catch (error) {
        console.error(error);
      }
    });
  });
});

Problem:

Even though I call await cds.tx({ tenant: null }, ...), the output of the above code always shows the subscriber's tenant schema, not the provider's schema. That means my query runs in the subscriber HDI container, not in the provider HDI container, even though I'm trying to connect to "providerDb".

What I'm trying to do:

I want to run an INSERT into the table APP_SUBSCRIPTION (defined only in the provider HDI container) during tenant subscription (inside ds.after('subscribe')).

Question:

How can I forcefully connect to and run a query inside the provider HDI container/schema during subscription?

  • Is cds.tx({ tenant: null }, ...) the right way?

  • Is there a special configuration needed in cds.connect.to("providerDb")?

  • How can I ensure the schema used is the one bound to the provider space?

Additional Info:

  • The destination providerDb is configured via cds.requires.providerDb in package.json.

Any help or working example would be appreciated.

entry.title: What's New in SAP Subscription Billing (Q2 2025)
entry.content:
Hello everyone, and welcome back to our quarterly blog series where we unveil the latest features in SAP Subscription Billing. As we continue to listen to your feedback and strive for excellence, we're excited to share the new and enhanced functionalities from Q2 2025. Let's explore!

Generate Dynamic Properties for Enhanced Pricing Flexibility

Introducing a powerful new capability within the Manage Price Element Specifications app‚Äîgenerate properties based on existing properties, fields, or constant values using the Define Property operator. This feature allows you to create dynamic properties as components in your pricing tree, offering unparalleled flexibility. For detailed guidance, see Define Property.

Pricing for Usage Aggregated Across Billing Cycles

We're excited to announce that you can now establish prices for usage aggregated over multiple billing cycles. This feature is ideal for implementing tiered pricing models, ensuring lower prices in higher tiers. Activate aggregation in rate plan templates under Cross-Billing Cycle Aggregation, with options to reset or continue indefinitely. Supporting APIs have been updated to align with this feature.

Example: Yearly Usage Invoiced Monthly

Imagine you want to price usage yearly with tiered pricing but want to invoice customers monthly. You can now define an aggregation period for usage, for example a year, and set up a billing cycle shorter than the aggregation period like a month. Each month, prices are determined for the customer's usage up to the current month within the year. After the year is over, you want to reset the aggregration. In this use case, if customers use a significant amount of a service annually, they could benefit from lower monthly prices in higher tiers, reflecting their cumulative yearly usage‚Äîa powerful way to incentivize higher consumption with attractive pricing.

For a practical how-to guide to setting up such a scenario, check out our blog on configuring cross-billing cycle aggregation for tier-based pricing: link to blog.

Streamlined Integration with SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition

We've simplified the transfer of billing data with direct integration for Sales Billing within SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, deprecating the previous SAP Cloud Integration approach. This direct integration eliminates licensing complexities, allowing seamless data transfer and master data replication via SAP Master Data Integration. Explore more in Transfer of Billing Data to Sales Billing.

Business Logic Extensibility

You now have the ability to extend the business logic of SAP Subscription Billing, opening up new avenues for customizing and optimizing workflows. With the newly introduced app, you can easily view all available extension points. This centralized view allows you to effectively plan and implement your modifications.

The first prominent use case for this expanded business logic is the direct integration of billing data into SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition. The provided service allows you to adjust the existing mapping logic between SAP Subscription Billing and SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, ensuring a seamless data transfer tailored to your specific business needs.

Looking ahead, we are developing more use cases and planning additional extension points to further enhance business logic extensibility. This ongoing expansion will empower users to tailor their systems to meet evolving business requirements, ensuring continued alignment with operational goals.

Unleash Insights with Data Analyzer Functions

Elevate your data exploration capabilities using SAP Analytics Cloud data analyzer. Perform ad-hoc analysis and save your drill-down insights in the Subscription Analytics and Billing Data Analytics apps. Dive deeper into your subscription business data through intuitive and insightful reporting functions. Learn more in Analytics.

Refined Usability with Enhanced Filters

Discover new ways to manage subscriptions with additional field filters in the Manage Subscriptions app, including Changed By, Created By, Ship-to Party, and Bill-to Party. Also, benefit from multiple value filters across key identifiers and attributes, both in Manage Subscriptions and Manage Billing Data apps. This enhancement optimizes search efficiency, supported by easy input methods to select desired values.

That concludes the great set of features delivered in Q2 2025 for SAP Subscription Billing! We hope these enhancements empower your business operations. For further feature details, visit our SAP Subscription Billing "What's New" page on SAP Help.
We encourage you to share your feedback, ask questions, or follow the SAP Subscription Billing tag to stay updated.

Until next quarter, keep innovating and take care!
Christian

More Information About SAP Subscription Billing

  • What‚Äôs New
  • SAP Help Portal Page
  • Feature Overview

entry.title: Re: HANA Client for Node.js and explicit connection pooling
entry.content:
Hello,

W.r.t the maxPooledIdleTime, unfortunately, our current implementation doesn‚Äôt proactively evict expired pooled connections unless another pooled connection is requested from or returned into the pool.

In other words, the behaviour ‚Äúif the connection is idle for longer then 60s, it is still kept open. Only once I do another request and a connection is to be taken from the pool, it evicts the old connection and creates a new one‚Äù mentioned in the thread is the expected behaviour based on our current implementation.

entry.title: Re: Handling Monthly Commission Payments Outside Standard...
entry.content:
Hi Chaima,

Set-up the Condition Contract as a fixed amount contract and post the delta accruals every month.

For Settlement: 

1. Run the commission settlement only after you receive the invoice from vendor(WB2R_SV). Fixed amount will be settled to vendor.

2. If you want only the incoming Invoice amount to be paid to the vendor, go with the manual settlement process(WB2R_DOC_ENTRY)

If you make the payment outside of CCM, you have to reverse the open accruals sitting on the condition contract manually. So better to CCM-Settlement for payments so that the accruals gets reversed automatically. 

Regards

Hari

entry.title: Re: Automatic Triggering of Release Universal Journal
entry.content:
SAP S/4HANA Finance for Group Reporting doesn't have a standard program to extract consolidated data from ACDOCA for file upload to ACDOCU in a way that directly mimics the EC-CS process for external upload. This is because Group Reporting is designed for direct integration and real-time consolidation within S/4HANA, primarily leveraging ACDOCA as its source.

Try custom route..

Since you're on S/4HANA 2023 Private Cloud, developing a custom ABAP program is the most flexible and robust solution.
Logic: The program would read relevant data from ACDOCA based on your consolidation-specific criteria (e.g., company codes, consolidation chart of accounts, GL accounts, posting periods, transaction types, partner information). It would then transform and format this data into the structure required for upload to ACDOCU.
Output Format: You can program it to output the data in a CSV or XML file format, which can then be used for upload.
Key Considerations:
-Mapping: You'll need to define clear mapping rules between ACDOCA fields and ACDOCU fields, considering dimensions like Consolidation Unit, Partner Consolidation Unit, Consolidation G/L Account, Transaction Type, etc.
-Data Aggregation/Transformation: Depending on your reporting requirements, you might need to aggregate certain accounts or perform specific transformations (e.g., currency translation if not already handled by Group Reporting's real-time processes, or reclassifications).
-Selection Criteria: Ensure robust selection parameters for company codes, fiscal periods, and other relevant master data to extract only the necessary data.
-Performance: For large volumes of data, optimize the program for performance.

If you find my response helpful, kindly accept the answer and award a Kudos. This motivates me to serve you better.
Appreciate your feedback.
Thanks,
Divyesh

entry.title: Re: Depreciation not posted in some Depreciation Areas
entry.content:
Hi @bjaganathan1 ,

Please verify couple of things..

1. Check Depreciation Area Settings - Transaction OADB
Verify whether the new depreciation areas are set to post to G/L. If "Post to G/L" is not checked, no depreciation entries will be posted, even if values are calculated.

2. Check Accounting Principle Assignment to Depreciation Areas
In S/4HANA (and ECC pre-S/4 with New GL), depreciation areas are linked to accounting principles. Use Transaction: S_ALR_87009183 or View: V_T093C. Ensure that the correct accounting principle is assigned. The depreciation area is linked to the correct ledger.
If the area isn't linked to a ledger, it will calculate values but not post.

3. Check Depreciation Key Settings - Go to AFAMA
Ensure depreciation keys in new areas are active and properly configured. Check for calculation method, Useful life, base method, declining/balancing
A blank or misconfigured key can prevent depreciation from being calculated or posted.

4. Check Posting Rules for Each Area (Transaction AO90)
Posting rules determine which accounts are used when posting depreciation. If the posting rule is missing or incomplete for the area, depreciation will not post.
Ensure entries exist for:
-Transaction type: 70 (Ordinary depreciation)
-Dep. area-specific GL mapping

If you find my response helpful, kindly accept the answer and award a Kudos. This motivates me to serve you better.
Appreciate your feedback.
Thanks,
Divyesh

entry.title: Re: Badi FIN_ACDOC_ITEM_VALIDATION does not have necessar...
entry.content:
Hi @Aish16 ,

Try Badi - FI_OUTGOING_PAYMENT_VALIDATION

Logic..
1.Get the House Bank and Account ID from the current payment being processed (this should be available in the payment header or a specific parameter of this BAdI).
2.Loop through the OPEN_ITEMS (vendor invoices) being selected for payment.
3.For each invoice, you'll need to read the original invoice document (from ACDOCA).
-How to read ACDOCA: You cannot directly SELECT * FROM ACDOCA in a custom BAdI in Public Cloud. You must use released CDS Views or APIs for data access.
-Identify the CDS view that exposes the vendor invoice details. Common ones include I_JournalEntryItem or views specifically designed for supplier invoices.
-The challenge: House bank is not a standard field on the vendor invoice line item in ACDOCA or related views. The house bank is typically determined at the time of payment or is part of your own bank details (for customer payments) or vendor's bank details (for supplier payments).

If you find my response helpful, kindly accept the answer and award a Kudos. This motivates me to serve you better.
Appreciate your feedback.
Thanks,
Divyesh

entry.title: Ensuring Exam Access Only After Class Completion
entry.content:
Hello experts

We have this client request: The client requires that, in a blended item, a learner should not be able to access the associated assessment without first completing a class.

Scenarios:

Scenario 1

The learner attends the class and passes it.

The learner gains access to the exam.

Scenario 2

The learner attends the class but does not pass it.

The learner does not gain access to the exam.

The learner is enrolled in another class (for the same item).

After passing it, the learner gains access to the exam.

 

Options evaluated so far:

1. Using prerequisites between components.

2. Splitting components into separate items (one for the class and another for the exam).

3. Using the instructor‚Äôs verification code (proctor code).

4. Enabling the exam only in a specific segment of the class.

Question: Do you have any additional options or alternative approaches that could fulfill this access control requirement?

Thanks in advance!

entry.title: 2508 Early Release Series for SAP Ariba and SAP Business Network releases
entry.content:
Sign up now for the 2508 Early Release Series

Follow this blog to receive notification of new series as soon as registration opens.

 

 

 

 

 

 

SAP strives to equip our customers and partners with valuable release readiness resources for each SAP Ariba and SAP Business Network quarterly release.

Early Release Series

The Early Release Series webcasts cover features planned for the upcoming SAP Ariba and SAP Business Network quarterly release.  This platform, available to customers and partners, has a clear mission: deliver an interactive forum to engage with SAP product experts providing simple, direct answers to your most pressing questions.  There is a different session for each product area with content tailored for the specific audience:

  • Supplier Management & Risk
  • Procure to Pay
  • Source to Contract

Note: With this release, the Early Release Series will not include a SAP Business Network session.

If you want to learn more and actively engage with SAP subject matter experts, we encourage you to participate in these informative sessions.  Register now!

Quarterly Release Communications

Notice of upcoming quarterly releases will be communicated to Buyer customers three weeks prior to the release date.  Suppliers receive notice two weeks prior.  Releases are communicated via email notification (look for subject line starting with: Advance Release Notice).

Anyone from your organization that has chosen to subscribe to product notifications will receive these announcements. 

The release calendar for SAP Business Network  and release calendar SAP Ariba Applications identify release timing several quarters in advance.

Where to find out more details?

On demand replays of webcasts from completed quarterly releases can be consumed from Release Readiness Resources: Webcast Archive Page

entry.title: How to prevent deletion of specific entry in Event 03 (Table Maintenance) when choose multiple rows
entry.content:
Hi experts, I am using Event 03: Before Deleting the Data for my table ZSAP03_EMAIL Now I write this FORM to prevent user from deleting user with USER_ID = DEV-145. When I delete a line with DEV-145 the system works correctly, but when I select multiple lines, including DEV-145 the system deletes DEV-145 as well. Please give me detailed solutions

 

FORM on_delete.
FIELD-SYMBOLS: <fs_user_id> TYPE any.

ASSIGN COMPONENT 'USER_ID' OF STRUCTURE <vim_total_struc> TO <fs_user_id>.

IF sy-subrc = 0 AND <fs_user_id> = 'DEV-145'.

MESSAGE 'Default row DEV-145 cannot be deleted!' TYPE 'E'.
ENDIF.
ENDFORM.

entry.title: Display Changes to Objects
entry.content:
This analytical application lets you review the recorded field changes for an object.

Screen Areas

Information filter

You can use the information filter at the top of the screen to select which data is displayed in the chart and table. This allows you to view recorded field changes for objects in various ways. You must enter the Object and Time Interval, as they are mandatory filters. Additionally, you can use other filters, such as "Object Component" and "Changed By", among others.

Fig. 2: Filter bar

Visual filter

Visual filter provides a graphical interface for interacting with and filtering your data. It allows you to view and filter the frequency of Changes to Fields based on "Change Type", "Year and Calendar Week" as well as by "Object Component" such as Item or Schedule Line.

Fig. 3: Visual filter bar

Bar chart

The bar chart offers a concise overview of the frequency of specific change fields. By selecting a bar, you can filter the entries in the table. Additionally, utilize the View By filter to explore different dimensional data. You also have the option to change the chart type from the default bar chart for other kinds of charts.

Fig. 4: Bar chart in Hybrid view

Fig. 5: Bar chart in Chart-only view

The "Hybrid view," also referred to as "Chart and Table View," is the default setting that displays both the chart and the table simultaneously. Additionally, you have the option to toggle between "Chart-only view" and "Table-only view" within the chart area.

Fig. 6: Toolbar in chart area

Table

The table located at the bottom of the screen provides additional details regarding the logged changes to objects, including Change Field, Change Type, Object IDs, Changed By, Old Value, and New Value. In the "Settings" button, you have the option to customize the displayed columns to include information such as Object Keys, Activity ID, Source of Data, and more. Additionally, you can utilize the "Group By" and "Sort by" features for the columns.

Fig. 7: Table in Table-only view

Upon clicking on column "Object IDs" you will be directed to the details page of the Fiori app "Display Business Events by Business Object".

Fig. 8: Details page of Display Business Events by Business Object

Upon clicking on each row in the "Change Type" column, you are directly directed to the event details page (Fiori app "Display Business Event Logs"),  or a dialog popover appears, displaying concise event information.

Fig. 9: Event Type and Versions in a Dialog

Upon selecting a table entry, you will be directed to the details page of the Fiori app "Display Business Event Logs".

Fig. 10: Details page of Display Business Event Logs

Release Information

ProductAvailability
SAP S/4 HANA Cloud, Public Edition2502 and later
SAP S/4 HANA Cloud, Private Edition2025 FPS0 and later
SAP S/4 HANA (On-Premise)2025 FPS0 and later
SAP BTP,  ABAP Environment 2411

Fiori Apps Library Reference

SAP S/4 HANA Cloud, Public Edition: https://fioriappslibrary.hana.ondemand.com/sap/fix/externalViewer/#/detail/Apps('F8211')/S34

entry.title: Re: Êú™‰ΩøÁî®„ÅÆICF„Çµ„Éº„Éì„Çπ„Å´„Å§„ÅÑ„Å¶
entry.content:
If the system for that you review the EarlyWatch Alert (EWA) Report sends EWA data to SAP, you can open the EarlyWatch Alert Dashboard, accessible via the EWA Workspace in SAP for Me, to enter the details page of the ICF Security chart within the User Experience section. Under the tab "Not used" you find the candidates for deactivation.
Important: Deactivate ICF services of usable apps and reuse libraries only if you are sure they are not utilized. Please double-check the ICF services listed under Not Used before deactivating.
For the deactivation of ICF services a mass processing tool is available. Please refer to SAP Note 2989913.
If you are unable to access the EarlyWatch Alert Dashboard, please refer to SAP Note 2520319.

More details, please refer 3261151 - SAPUI5 Apps - Identify unused ICF services.

entry.title: Re: Single Bonus Payout after Termination and Rehire with...
entry.content:
Hi @RaviUpadhyay 

There is no automated solution for this. By design we calculate payout for each period the employee had under each userID. 

The only way to do this is for customers to handle these cases manually: 

  1. Import both records for both userID from EC
  2. For each employee in this situation find the record from the old country, export its salary/earnings data, convert it into the currency of the new country and sum it up with the salary/earning of the new country record. Then run bonus calculation, and delete the employee history record of the old country.

I looked for workarounds with MDF for this and couldn't find any.

All the best,

Xavier

If you want the output to be 9:00 PM CDT, the UTC time should be:

Because:
- 2:00 AM UTC ‚àí 5 hours = 9:00 PM CDT on April 2
